This includes in it all obedience, and, where it is genuine, will produce all the fruits of it; and where it was not, no multiplication of duties was accepted with him. But this in general we do not now treat of.

That the person of Christ is the specialAuto-modernized object of this divine love, which is the fire that kindles the sacrifice of our obedience toAuto-modernized him -- this is that alone which at present I design to demonstrate.

The apostle hasAuto-modernized recorded a very severe denunciation of divine wrath against all that love him not: "If any man love not the Lord Jesus Christ, let him be Anathema Maranatha," 1 Corinthians 16:22 And what was added toAuto-modernized the curse of the Law we may add toAuto-modernized this of the Gospel: "And all the people shall say, Amen," Deuteronomy 27:26 And, on the other hand, he prays for grace on all that "love him in sincerity," Ephesians 6:24 ThereforeAuto-modernized, none who desire to retain the name of Christian, can deny, in words at least, but that we ought, with all our hearts, to love the Lord Jesus Christ.

I do not so distinguish love from obedience as though it were not itself a part, yea, the chiefest part, of our obedience. So is faith also; yet is it constantly distinguished from obedience, properly so called. This alone is that which I shall demonstrate -- namely, that there is, and ought to be, in all believers, a divine, gracious love toAuto-modernized the person of Christ, immediately fixed on him, through whichAuto-modernized they are excited toAuto-modernized, and acted in, all their obedience toAuto-modernized his authority. Had it been only pleaded, that many who pretend love toAuto-modernized Christ do yet evidence that they love him not, it is that which the Scripture testifiesAuto-modernized, and continual experience doesAuto-modernized proclaim. If an application of this charge had been made toAuto-modernized them whose sincerity in their profession of love toAuto-modernized him can be no way evidenced, it ought to be borne with patience, amongst other reproaches of the same kind that are cast upon them. And some things are to be premised toAuto-modernized the confirmation of our assertion.

1. It is granted that there may be a false pretence of love toAuto-modernized Christ; and as this pretence is ruinous toAuto-modernized the souls of them in whom it is, so it ofttimes renders them prejudicial and troublesome toAuto-modernized others. There ever were, and probably ever will be, hypocrites in the church and a false pretence of love is of the essential form of hypocrisy. The first great act of hypocrisy, with respect toAuto-modernized Christ, was treachery, veiled with a double pretence of love. He cried, "Hail, Master! and kissed him," who betrayed him. His words and actions proclaimed love, but deceit and treachery were in his heart. Hence the apostle prays for grace on them who love the Lord Jesus en aphtharsia -- without dissimulation or doubling, without pretences and aims at other ends, without a mixture of corrupt affections; that is, in sincerity, Ephesians 6:24 It was prophesied of him, that many who were strangers toAuto-modernized his grace should lie toAuto-modernized him, Psalms 18:44, bny nkr ykchshvly -- feignedly submit, or yield feigned obedience toAuto-modernized him. So is it with them who profess love toAuto-modernized him, yet are enemies of his cross, "whose end is destruction, whose god is their belly, and whose glory is in their shame, who mind earthly things," Philippians 3:18-19 All that are called Christians in the world, do, by owning that denomination, profess a love toAuto-modernized Jesus Christ; but greater enemies, greater haters of him, he hasAuto-modernized not among the children of men, than many of them are. This falsely pretended love is worse than avowed hatred; neither will the pretence of it stand men in stead at the last day. No other answer will be given toAuto-modernized the plea of it, be it in whom it will, but "Depart from me, I never knew you, ye workers of iniquity." Whereas, therefore, he himself hasAuto-modernized prescribed this rule toAuto-modernized all who would be esteemed his disciples, "If ye love me, keep my commandments," we may safely conclude, all who live in a neglect of his commands, whatever they pretend or profess, they love him not. And the satisfaction which men, through much darkness, and many corrupt prejudices, have attained toAuto-modernized in the profession of Christian religion, without an internal, sincere love toAuto-modernized Christ himself, is that which ruins religion and their own souls.

2. As there is a false pretence of love toAuto-modernized Christ, so there is, or may be, a false love toAuto-modernized him also. The persons in whom it is may in some measure be sincere, and yet their love toAuto-modernized Christ may not be pure, nor sincere -- such as answers the principles and rules of the gospel; and as many deceive others, so some deceive themselves in this matter. They may think that they love Christ, but indeed do not so; and this I shall manifest in some few instances.

(1.) That love is not sincere and incorrupt which proceedsAuto-modernized not from -- which is not a fruit of faith. Those who do not first really believe on Christ, can never sincerely love him. It is faith alone that worksAuto-modernized by love towards Christ and all his saints. If, therefore, any do not believe with that faith which unites them toAuto-modernized Christ, which within purifies the heart, and is outwardly effectual in duties of obedience, whatever they may persuade themselves concerning love toAuto-modernized Christ, it is but a vain delusion. Where the faith of men is dead, their love will not be living and sincere.

(2.) That love is not so which arisesAuto-modernized from false ideas and representations that men make of Christ, or have made of him in their minds. Men may draw images in their minds of what they most fancy, and then dote upon them. So some think of Christ only as a glorious person exalted in heaven at the right hand of God, without farther apprehensions of his natures and offices. So the Roman missionaries represented him toAuto-modernized some of the Indians -- concealing from them his cross and sufferings. But every false notion concerning his person or his grace -- what he is, hasAuto-modernized done, or doesAuto-modernized -- corrupts the love that is pretended toAuto-modernized him. Shall we think that they love Christ by whom his divine nature is denied or that those do so who disbelieve the reality of his human nature? Or those by whom the union of both in the same person is rejected? There cannot be true evangelical love toAuto-modernized a false Christ, such as these imaginations do fancy.

(3.) So is that love which is not in all things -- as to causes, motives, measures, and ends -- regulated by the Scripture. This alone gives us the nature, rules, and bounds of sincere spiritual love. We are no more to love Christ, than to fear and worship him, according toAuto-modernized our own imaginations. From the Scripture are we to derive all the principles and motives of our love. If either the acts or effects of it will not endure a trial thereby, they are false and counterfeit; and many such have been pretended toAuto-modernized, as we shall see immediately.

(4.) That is so, unquestionably, which fixesAuto-modernized itself on undue objects, which, whatever is pretended, are neither Christ nor means of conveying our love toAuto-modernized him. Such is all that love which the Romanists express in their devotion toAuto-modernized images, as they fancy, of Christ; crucifixes, pretended relics of his cross, and the nails that pierced him, with the like superstitious representations of him, and what they suppose he is concerned in. For although they express their devotion with great appearance of ardent affections, under all outward signs of them -- in adorations, kissings, prostrations, with sighs and tears; yet all this while it is not Christ which they thus cleave toAuto-modernized, but a cloud of their own imaginations, with whichAuto-modernized their carnal minds are pleased and affected. That is no god which a man hews out of a tree, though he form it for that end, though he falls down toAuto-modernized it and worshipsAuto-modernized it, and praysAuto-modernized toAuto-modernized it, and saysAuto-modernized, "Deliver me, for thou art my god," Isaiah 44:17 The authors of this superstition, through whichAuto-modernized the love of innumerable poor souls is depraved and abused, do first frame in their minds what they suppose may solicit or draw out the natural and carnal affections of men toAuto-modernized it, and then outwardly represent it as an object for them. ThereforeAuto-modernized some of their representations of him are glorious, and some of them dolorous, according as they aim to excite affections in carnal minds. But, as I said, these things are not Christ, nor is he any way concerned in them.

(5.) I acknowledge there have been great pretences of such a love toAuto-modernized Christ as cannot be justified. Such is that which some of the devotionists of the Roman Church have endeavoured rather to express out of their fancy than declare out of their experience. Raptures, ecstasies, self-annihilations, immediate adhesions and enjoyments, without any act of the understanding, and with a multitude of other swelling words of vanity, they labour to set off what they fancy to be divine love. But there wants not evidences of truth sufficient to defeat these pretences, be they ever so specious or glorious. For --

[1.] As it is by them described, it exceedsAuto-modernized all Scripture precedents. For men to assume toAuto-modernized themselves an apprehension that they love Christ in another manner and kind, in a higher degree at least, and thence to enjoy more intimacy with him, more love from him, than did any of the apostles -- John, or Paul, or Peter, or any other of those holy ones whose love toAuto-modernized him is recorded in the Scripture -- is intolerable vanity and presumption. But no such things as these devotees pretend toAuto-modernized are mentioned, or in the least intimated concerning them, and their love to their Lord and Master. No man will pretend toAuto-modernized more love than they had, but such as have none at all.

[2.] It is no way directed, warranted, approved, by any command, promise, or rule of the Scripture. As it is without precedent, so it is without precept. And hereby, whether we will or no, all our graces and duties must be tried, as toAuto-modernized any acceptation with God. Whatever pretends to exceed the direction of the Word may safely be rejected -- cannot safely be admitted. Whatever enthusiasms or pretended inspirations may be pleaded for the singular practice of what is prescribed in the Scripture, yet none can be allowed for an approved principle of what is not so prescribed. Whatever exceeds the bounds of thatAuto-modernized is resolved into the testimony of every distempered imagination. Nor will it avail that these things amongst them are submitted toAuto-modernized the judgment of the church. For the church hasAuto-modernized no rule to judge by but the Scripture; and it can pass but one judgment of what is not warranted thereby -- namely, that it is to be rejected.

[3.] As it is described by those who applaud it, it is not suited toAuto-modernized the sober, sedate actings of the rational faculties of our souls. For whereas all that God requiresAuto-modernized of us, is that we love him with all our souls and all our minds, these men cry up a divine love by an immediate adhesion of the will and the affections toAuto-modernized God, without any actings of the mind and understanding at all. Love, indeed, is the regular acting of our whole souls, by all their faculties and rational powers, in an adherence toAuto-modernized God. But these men have fancied a divine love for them whom they would admire and extol, which disturbs all their regular acting, and renders them of little or no use in that which, without their due exercise, is nothing but fancy. And hence it is that, under pretence of this love, sundry persons among them -- yea, all that have pretended toAuto-modernized it -- have fallen into such ridiculous excesses and open delusions as sufficiently discover the vanity of the love itself pretended by them.

ThereforeAuto-modernized we plead for no other love toAuto-modernized the person of Christ but what the Scripture warrants as toAuto-modernized its nature; what the gospel requiresAuto-modernized of us as our duty; what the natural faculties of our minds are suited toAuto-modernized and given us for; what they are enabled toAuto-modernized by grace; and without which in some degree of sincerity, no man can yield acceptable obedience toAuto-modernized him.

These things being premised, that which we assert is, that there is, and ought to be, in all believers, a religious, gracious love toAuto-modernized the person of Christ, distinct from, and the reason of, their obedience toAuto-modernized his commands; -- that is, it is distinct from all other commands; but is also itself commanded and required of us in a way of duty.

That there is in the church such a love toAuto-modernized the person of Christ, the Scripture testifies, both in the precepts it gives for it and the examples of it. And all those who truly believe cannot apprehend that they understand any thing of faith, or love of Christ, or themselves, by whom it is called in question. If, therefore, I should enlarge on this subject, a great part of the doctrine of the Scripture from first to last must be represented and a transcript of the hearts of believers, in whichAuto-modernized this love is seated and prevalent, be made, according to our ability. And there is no subject that I could more willingly enlarge upon. But I must at present contract myself, in compliance with my design. Two things only I shall demonstrate: 1. That the person of Christ is the object of divine love; 2. What is the nature of that love in us; what are the grounds of it, and the motives toAuto-modernized it, in them that do believe.
In reference toAuto-modernized the first of these, the ensuing position shall be the subject of the remainder of this chapter.
The person of Christ is the principal object of the love of God, and of the whole creation participant of his image. The reason why I thus extend the assertion will appear in the declaration of it.

(1.) No small part of the eternal blessedness of the holy God consistsAuto-modernized in the mutual love of the Father and the Son, by the Spirit. As he is the only-begotten of the Father, he is the first, necessary, adequate, complete object of the whole love of the Father. Hence he says of himself, that from eternity he was "by him, as one brought up with him: and was daily his delight, rejoicing always before him," Proverbs 8:30 -- which place was opened before. In him was the ineffable, eternal, unchangeable delight and complacency of the Father, as the full object of his love. The same is expressed in that description of him, John 1:18, "The only-begotten Son, who is in the bosom of the Father." His being the only-begotten Son declares his eternal relation toAuto-modernized the person of the Father, of whom he was begotten in the entire communication of the whole divine nature. Upon thisAuto-modernized he is in the bosom of the Father -- in the eternal embraces of his love, as his only-begotten Son. The Father loves, and cannot but love, his own nature and essential image in him.

In thisAuto-modernized originally is God love: "For God is love," 1 John 4:8 This is the fountain and prototype of all love, as being eternal and necessary. All other acts of love are in God but emanations from hence, and effects of it. As he doesAuto-modernized good because he is good, so he lovesAuto-modernized because he is love. He is love eternally and necessarily in this love of the Son; and all other workings of love are but acts of his will, through whichAuto-modernized somewhat of it is outwardly expressed. And all love in the creation was introduced from this fountain, to give a shadow and resemblance of it.

Love is that which contemplative men have always almost adored. Many things have they spoken to evince it to be the light, life, lustre and glory of the whole creation. But the original and pattern of it was always hid from the wisest philosophers of old. Something they reached after about God's love toAuto-modernized himself, with rest and complacency in his own infinite excellencies; but of this ineffable mutual love of the Father and the Son, both in and by that Spirit which proceeds from them both, they had neither apprehension nor conjecture. Yet, as in thisAuto-modernized doesAuto-modernized the principal part (if we may so speak) of the blessedness of the holy God consist, so is it the only fountain and prototype of all that is truly called love; -- a blessing and glory which the creation had never been made partaker of, but only to express, according to the capacity of their several natures, this infinite and eternal love of God! For God's love of himself -- which is natural and necessary toAuto-modernized the Divine Being -- consists in the mutual complacency of the Father and the Son by the Spirit. And it was to express himself, that God made any thing without himself. He made the heavens and the earth to express his being, goodness, and power. He created man "in his own image," to express his holiness and righteousness; and he implanted love in our natures to express this eternal mutual love of the holy persons of the Trinity. But we must leave it under the veil of infinite incomprehensibleness; though admiration and adoration of it be not without the highest spiritual satisfaction.

Again, he is the peculiar object of the love of the Father, of the love of God, as he is incarnate -- as he hasAuto-modernized taken on him, and hasAuto-modernized now discharged, the work of mediation, or continues in the discharge of it; that is, the person of Christ, as God-man, is the peculiar object of the divine love of the Father. The person of Christ in his divine nature is the adequate object of that love of the Father which is "ad intra" -- a natural necessary act of the divine essence in its distinct personal existence; and the person of Christ as incarnate, as clothed with human nature, is the first and full object of the love of the Father in those acts of it which are "ad extra", or are towards anything without himself. So he declares himself in the prospect of his future incarnation and work, "Behold my servant, whom I uphold; mine elect, in whom my soul delightsAuto-modernized," Isaiah 42:1 The delight of the soul of God, his rest and complacency -- which are the great effects of love -- are in the Lord Christ, as his elect and servant in the work of mediation. And the testimony of thisAuto-modernized he renewed twice from heaven afterwards, Matthew 3:17, "Lo, a voice from heaven, saying, This is my beloved Son, in whom I am well pleased;" as it is again repeated, Matthew 17:5 All things are disposed to give a due sense toAuto-modernized us of this love of God toAuto-modernized him. The testimony concerning it is twice repeated in the same words from heaven. And the words of it are emphatical toAuto-modernized the utmost of our comprehension: "My Son, my servant, mine elect, my beloved Son, in whom I rest, in whom I delight, and am well pleased." It is the will of God to leave upon our hearts a sense of this love toAuto-modernized Christ; for his voice came from heaven, not for his sake, who was always filled with a sense of this divine love, but for ours, that we might believe it.

This he pleaded as the foundation of all the trust reposed in him, and all the power committed toAuto-modernized him. "The Father lovesAuto-modernized the Son, and hasAuto-modernized given all things into his hand," John 3:35 "The Father lovesAuto-modernized the Son, and showsAuto-modernized him all things that himself doesAuto-modernized," John 5:20John 23, 26. And the sense or due apprehension of it is the foundation of Christian religion. Hence he prays that we may know that God hasAuto-modernized loved him,

In this sense, the person of Christ is the proton dektikon -- the first recipient subject of all that divine love which extends itself toAuto-modernized the church. It is all, the whole of it, in the first place fixed upon him, and by and through him is communicated toAuto-modernized the church. Whatever it receives in grace and glory, it is but the streams of this fountain -- love toAuto-modernized himself. So he prays for all his disciples, "that the love," saysAuto-modernized he, "with whichAuto-modernized thou hast loved me may be in them, and I in them," John 17:26 They can be partakers of no other love, neither in itself nor in its fruits, but that alone with whichAuto-modernized the Father first loved him. He lovesAuto-modernized him for us all, and us no otherwise but as in him. He makes us "accepted in the Beloved," Ephesians 1:6 He is the Beloved of the Father kat' exochen; as in all things he was to have the pre-eminence, Colossians 1:18 The love of the body is derived toAuto-modernized it from the love toAuto-modernized the Head; and in the love of him doesAuto-modernized God love the whole church, and no otherwise. He loves none but as united toAuto-modernized him, and participant of his nature.

ThereforeAuto-modernized the love of the Father toAuto-modernized the Son, as the only begotten, and the essential image of his person, in whichAuto-modernized the ineffable delight of the divine nature doesAuto-modernized consist, was the fountain and cause of all love in the creation, by an act of the will of God for its representation. And the love of God the Father toAuto-modernized the person of Christ as incarnate, being the first adequate object of divine love in whichAuto-modernized there is anything "ad extra," is the fountain and specialAuto-modernized cause of all gracious love towards us and in us. And our love toAuto-modernized Christ being the only outward expression and representation of this love of the Father toAuto-modernized him, in thatAuto-modernized consists the principal part of our renovation into his image. Nothing renders us so like toAuto-modernized God as our love toAuto-modernized Jesus Christ, for he is the principal object of his love, -- in him doesAuto-modernized his soul rest -- in him is he always well pleased. Wherever this is wanting, whatever there may be besides, there is nothing of the image of God. He that loves not Jesus Christ, let him be Anathema Maranatha; for he is unlike toAuto-modernized God, -- his canal mind is enmity against God.

(2.) Among those who are in the image of God, the angels above are of the first consideration. We are, indeed, as yet much in the dark toAuto-modernized the things that are "within the veil." They are above us as toAuto-modernized our present capacity, and hid from us as toAuto-modernized our present state; but there is enough in the Scripture to manifest the adhesion of angels toAuto-modernized the person of Christ by divine love. For love proceeding from sight is the life of the church above; as love proceeding from faith is the life of the church below. And this life the angels themselves do live. For --

[1.] They were all, toAuto-modernized their inexpressible present advantage and security for the future, brought into that recovery and recapitulation of all things which God hasAuto-modernized made in him. He hasAuto-modernized "gathered together in one all things in Christ, both which are in heaven, and which are on earth, even in him," Ephesians 1:10 The things in heaven, and things on earth -- angels above, and men below -- were originally united in the love of God. God's love toAuto-modernized them, from whereAuto-modernized springs their mutual love between themselves, was a bond of union between them, rendering them one complete family of God in heaven and earth, as it is called, Ephesians 3:15 On the entrance of sin, through whichAuto-modernized mankind forfeited their interest in the love of God, and lost all love toAuto-modernized him, or anything for him, this union was utterly dissolved, and mutual enmity came into the place of its principle in love. God is pleased to gather up these divided parts of his family into one -- in one head, which is Christ Jesus. And as there is hereby a union established again between angels and the church in love, so their adherence toAuto-modernized the head, the centre, life, and spring of this union, is by love, and no otherwise. It is not faith, but love, that is the bond of this union between Christ and them; and in thisAuto-modernized no small part of their blessedness and glory in heaven doesAuto-modernized consist.

[2.] That worship, adoration, service, and obedience, which they yield toAuto-modernized him, are all in like manner animated with love and delight. In love they cleave toAuto-modernized him, in love they worship and serve him. They had a command to worship him on his nativity, Hebrews 1:6; and they did it with joy, exultation, and praises -- all effects of love and delight -- Luke 2:13-14 And as they continue about the throne of God, they say, with a loud voice, "Worthy is the Lamb that was slain to receive power, and riches, and wisdom, and strength, and honour, and glory, and blessing," Revelation of John 5:12 Their continual ascription of glory and praise toAuto-modernized him is an effect of reverential love and delight; and from thence also is their concernAuto-modernized in his gospel and grace, Ephesians 3:9-10; 1 Peter 1:12 Nor without this love in the highest degree can it be conceived how they should be blessed and happy in their continual employment. For they are "all ministering spirits, sent forth to minister for the heirs of salvation," Hebrews 1:14 Were they not acted in thisAuto-modernized by their fervent love toAuto-modernized Christ, they could have no delight in their own ministry.

We have not, we cannot have, in this world, a full comprehension of the nature of angelical love. Our notions are but dark and uncertain, in things of whichAuto-modernized we can have no experience. ThereforeAuto-modernized, we cannot have here a clear intuition into the nature of the love of spirits, whilst our own is mixed with what derives from the acting of the animal spirits of our bodies also. But the blessedness of angels doesAuto-modernized not consist in the endowments of their nature -- that they are great in power, light, knowledge, and wisdom; for, notwithstanding these things, many of them became devils. But the excellency and blessedness of the angelical state consist in these two things: 1^st, That they are disposed, and able constantly, inseparably, universally, uninterruptedly, to cleave toAuto-modernized God in love. And as they do so toAuto-modernized God, so they do toAuto-modernized the person of Christ; and through him, as their head, toAuto-modernized God, even the Father. 2^dly, Add to thisAuto-modernized that gracious reflex sense which they have of the glory, dignity, eternal sweetness, and satisfaction, which arise from hence, and we have the sum of angelical blessedness.

(3.) The church of mankind is the other part of the rational creation whereon the image of God is renewed. Love toAuto-modernized the person of Christ, proceeding from faith, is their life, their joy, and glory.

It was so toAuto-modernized the church under the Old Testament. The whole Book of Canticles is designed to no other purpose, but variously to shadow forth, to insinuate and represent, the mutual love of Christ and the church. Blessed is he who understands the sayings of that book, and hasAuto-modernized the experience of them in his heart. The 45^th Psalm, among others, is designed toAuto-modernized the same purpose. All the glorious descriptions which are given of his person in the residue of the prophets, were only means to excite love toAuto-modernized him, and desires after him. Hence is he called chmdt klhgvm, Haggai 2:7, "The Desire of all nations" -- he alone who is desirable toAuto-modernized, and the only beloved of the church gathered out of all nations.

The clear revelation of the person of Christ, so as to render him the direct object of our love, with the causes and reasons of it, is one of the most eminent privileges of the New Testament. And it is variously attested in precepts, promises, instances, and solemn approbations.

Wherever he supposesAuto-modernized or requiresAuto-modernized this love in any of his disciples, it is not only as their duty, as that which they were obliged toAuto-modernized by the precepts of the Gospel, but as that without which no other duty whatever is accepted by him. "If," saysAuto-modernized he "ye love me, keep my commandments," John 14:15 He so requires love toAuto-modernized himself, as not to expect or approve of any obedience toAuto-modernized his commands without it. It is a great and blessed duty to feed the sheep and lambs of Christ; yet will not he accept of it unless it proceeds out of love toAuto-modernized his person. "Simon, son of Jonas, lovest thou me? Feed my lambs," John 21:15-17 Three times did he repeat the same words to him who had failed in his love towards him, by denying him thrice. Without this love toAuto-modernized him, he requires of none to feed his sheep, nor will accept of what they pretend to do in thatAuto-modernized. It were a blessed thing, if a due apprehension of thisAuto-modernized did always abide with them that are called toAuto-modernized that work.

To thisAuto-modernized doesAuto-modernized he annex those blessed promises which comprise the whole of our peace, safety, and consolation in this world. "He," saysAuto-modernized he, "that lovesAuto-modernized me, shall be loved of my Father, and I will love him, and manifest myself toAuto-modernized him," John 14:21; and verse 23, "My Father will love him, and we will come toAuto-modernized him, and make our abode with him." What heart can conceive, what tongue can express, the glory of these promises, or the least part of the grace that is contained in them? Who can conceive aright of the divine condescension, love, and grace that are expressed in them? How little a portion is it that we know of God in these things! But if we value them not, if we labour not for an experience of them according toAuto-modernized our measure, we have neither lot nor portion in the gospel. The presence and abode of God with us as a Father, manifesting himself to be such toAuto-modernized us, in the infallible pledges and assurances of our adoption -- the presence of Christ with us, revealing himself toAuto-modernized us, with all those ineffable mercies with whichAuto-modernized these things are accompanied -- are all contained in them. And these promises are peculiarly given toAuto-modernized them that love the person of Christ, and in the exercise of love towards him.

To thisAuto-modernized are designed the Gospel Gerizim and Ebal -- the denunciation of blessings and curses. As blessings are declared to be their portion "who love the Lord Jesus in sincerity," Ephesians 6:24, -- so those who love him not, have the substance of all curses denounced against them, even "Anathema Maranatha," 1 Corinthians 16:22 So far shall such persons be, whatever they may profess of outward obedience toAuto-modernized the Gospel, from any blessed interest in the promises of it, as that they are justly liable toAuto-modernized final excision from the church in this world, and eternal malediction in that which is to come.

It is evident, therefore, that the love of the church of believers toAuto-modernized the person of Christ is not a distempered fancy, not a deluding imagination, as some have blasphemed; but that which the nature of their relation toAuto-modernized him makes necessary -- that in whichAuto-modernized they express their renovation into the image of God -- that which the Scripture indispensably requires of them, and whereon all their spiritual comfort do depend. These things being spoken in general, the particular nature, effects, operations, and motives of this divine love, must now be farther inquired into.

div.osisID: Chapter 13 The Nature Operations and Causes of Divine Love as it respects the Person of Christ
div.title: Chapter 13 The Nature, Operations, and Causes of Divine Love, as it respects the Person of Christ.
div.p: That we may the better understand that love toAuto-modernized the person of Christ which we plead for, some things must be premised concerning the nature of divine love in general; and upon thatAuto-modernized its application toAuto-modernized the particular acting and exercise of it which we inquire into will be plain and easy.

God hasAuto-modernized endowed our nature with a faculty and ability of fixing our love upon himself. Many can understand nothing of love but the adherence of their minds and souls toAuto-modernized things visible and sensible, capable of a present natural enjoyment. For things unseen, especially such as are eternal and infinite, they suppose they have a veneration, a religious respect, a devout adoration; but how they should love them, they cannot understand. And the apostle doesAuto-modernized grant that there is a greater difficulty in loving things that cannot be seen, than in loving those which are always visibly present toAuto-modernized us, 1 John 4:20 NeverthelessAuto-modernized, this divine love hasAuto-modernized a more fixed station and prevalence in the minds of men than any other kind of love whatever. For --

1. The principal end why God endued our natures with that great and ruling affection, that hasAuto-modernized the most eminent and peculiar power and interest in our souls, was, in the first place, that it might be fixed on himself -- that it might be the instrument of our adherence toAuto-modernized him. He did not create this affection in us, that we might be able by it to cast ourselves into the embraces of things natural and sensual. No affection hasAuto-modernized such power in the soul to cause it to cleave toAuto-modernized its object, and to work it into a conformity toAuto-modernized it. Most other affections are transient in their operations, and work by a transport of nature -- as anger, joy, fear, and the like; but love is capable of a constant exercise, is a spring toAuto-modernized all other affections, and unites the soul with an efficacy not easy to be expressed toAuto-modernized its object. And shall we think that God, who made all things for himself, did create this ruling affection in and with our natures, merely that we might be able to turn from him, and cleave toAuto-modernized other things with a power and faculty above any we have of adherence toAuto-modernized him? ThereforeAuto-modernized, at our first creation, and in our primitive condition, love was the very soul and quickening principle of the life of God; and on our adherence toAuto-modernized him thereby the continuance of our relation toAuto-modernized him did depend. The law, rule, and measure of it was, "Thou shalt love the Lord thy God with all thy heart, and all thy soul." For this end did God create this affection in us. Not only our persons in their nature and being, but in all their powers and faculties, were fitted and prepared toAuto-modernized this end, of living toAuto-modernized God, and coming toAuto-modernized the enjoyment of him. And all their exercise on created objects was to be directed toAuto-modernized this end. ThereforeAuto-modernized, the placing of our love on anything before God, or above him is a formal expression of our apostasy from him.

2. Divine excellencies are a proper, adequate object of our love. The will, indeed, can adhere toAuto-modernized nothing in love, but what the understanding apprehends as toAuto-modernized its truth and being; but it is not necessary that the understanding do fully comprehend the whole nature of that which the will doesAuto-modernized so adhere toAuto-modernized. Where a discovery is made toAuto-modernized and by the mind of real goodness and amiableness, the will there can close with its affections. And these are apprehended as absolutely the most perfect in the divine nature and holy properties of it. Whereas, therefore, not only that which is the proper object of love is in the divine excellencies, but it is there only perfectly and absolutely, without the mixture of anything that should give it an alloy, as there is in all creatures, they are the most suitable and adequate object of our love.

There is no greater discovery of the depravation of our natures by sin and degeneracy of our wills from their original rectitude, than that -- whereas we are so prone to the love of other things, and in thatAuto-modernized do seek for satisfaction toAuto-modernized our souls where it is not to be obtained -- it is so hard and difficult to raise our hearts toAuto-modernized the love of God.
Were it not for that depravation, he would always appear as the only suitable and satisfactory object toAuto-modernized our affections.

3. The specialAuto-modernized object of divine, gracious love, is the divine goodness. "How great is his goodness, how great is his beauty!" Zechariah 9:17 Nothing is amiable or a proper object of love, but what is good, and as it is so. Hence divine goodness, which is infinite, hasAuto-modernized an absolutely perfect amiableness accompanying it. Because his goodness is inexpressible, his beauty is so. "How great is his goodness, how great is his beauty!" Hence are we called to give thanks toAuto-modernized the Lord, and to rejoice in him -- which are the effects of love -- because he is good, Psalms 106:1; cxxxvi. 1.

Neither is divine goodness the specialAuto-modernized object of our love as absolutely considered; but we have a respect toAuto-modernized it as comprehensive of all that mercy, grace, and bounty, which are suited to give us the best relief in our present condition and an eternal future reward. Infinite goodness, exerting itself in all that mercy, grace, faithfulness, and bounty, which are needful toAuto-modernized our relief and blessedness in our present condition, is the proper object of our love. Whereas, therefore, this is done only in Christ, there can be no true love of the divine goodness, but in and through him alone.

The goodness of God, as a creator, preserver, and rewarder, was a sufficient, yea, the adequate object of all love antecedently toAuto-modernized the entrance of sin and misery. In them, in God under those considerations, might the soul of man find full satisfaction as toAuto-modernized its present and future blessedness. But since the passing of sin, misery, and death upon us, our love can find no amiableness in any goodness -- no rest, complacency, and satisfaction in any -- but what is effectual in that grace and mercy by Christ, which we stand in need of for our present recovery and future reward. Nor doesAuto-modernized God require of us that we should love him otherwise but as he "is in Christ reconciling the world toAuto-modernized himself." So the apostle fully declares it: "In this was manifested the love of God towards us, because that God sent his only-begotten Son into the world, that we might live through him. In thisAuto-modernized is love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and sent his Son to be the propitiation for our sins. And we have known and believed the love that God hasAuto-modernized to us. God is love; and he that dwellsAuto-modernized in love dwellsAuto-modernized in God, and God in him," 1 John 4:9-10, 16 God is love, of a nature infinitely good and gracious, so as to be the only object of all divine love. But this love can no way be known, or be so manifested toAuto-modernized us, as that we may and ought to love him, but by his love in Christ, his sending of him and loving us in him. Before this, without this, we do not, we cannot love God. For "in thisAuto-modernized is love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and sent his Son to be the propitiation for our sins." This is the cause, the spring and fountain, of all our love to him. They are but empty notions and imaginations, which some speculative persons please themselves withal, about love toAuto-modernized the divine goodness absolutely considered. For however infinitely amiable it may be in itself, it is not so really toAuto-modernized them, it is not suited toAuto-modernized their state and condition, without the consideration of the communications of it toAuto-modernized us in Christ.

4. These things being premised, we may consider the specialAuto-modernized nature of this divine love, although I acknowledge that the least part of what believers have an experience of in their own souls can be expressed at least by me. Some few things I shall mention, which may give us a shadow of it, but not the express image of the thing itself.

(1.) Desire of union and enjoyment is the first vital act of this love. The soul, upon the discovery of the excellencies of God, earnestly desires to be united toAuto-modernized them -- to be brought near toAuto-modernized that enjoyment of them of whichAuto-modernized it is capable, and in whichAuto-modernized alone it can find rest and satisfaction. This is essential toAuto-modernized all love; it unites the mind toAuto-modernized its object, and rests not but in enjoyment. God's love toAuto-modernized us arisesAuto-modernized out of the overflowing of his own immense goodness, of whichAuto-modernized he will communicate the fruits and effects toAuto-modernized us. God is love; and in thisAuto-modernized is love, not that we loved God, but that he loved us, and sent his only-begotten Son. Yet also doesAuto-modernized this love of God tend to the bringing of us toAuto-modernized him, not that he may enjoy us, but that he may be enjoyed by us. This answers the desire of enjoyment in us, Job 14:15: "Thou shalt call me;" (that is, out of the dust at the last day;) "thou wilt have a desire to the work of thine hands." God's love will not rest, until it hasAuto-modernized brought us toAuto-modernized himself. But our love toAuto-modernized God arisesAuto-modernized from a sense of our own wants -- our insufficiency to come toAuto-modernized rest in ourselves, or to attain toAuto-modernized blessedness by our own endeavours. In this state, seeing all in God, and expecting all from the suitableness of his excellencies toAuto-modernized our rest and satisfaction, our souls cleave toAuto-modernized him, with a desire of the nearest union of whichAuto-modernized our natures are capable. We are made for him, and cannot rest until we come toAuto-modernized him.

Our goodness extends not toAuto-modernized God; we cannot profit him by any thing that we are, or can do. ThereforeAuto-modernized, his love toAuto-modernized us hasAuto-modernized not respect originally toAuto-modernized any good in ourselves, but is a gracious, free act of his own. He doesAuto-modernized good for no other reason but because he is good. Nor can his infinite perfections take any cause for their original actings without himself. He wants nothing that he would supply by the enjoyment of us. But we have indigency in ourselves to cause our love to seek an object without ourselves. And so his goodness -- with the mercy, grace, and bounty included in thatAuto-modernized -- is the cause, reason, and object of our love. We love them for themselves; and because we are wanting and indigent, we love them with a desire of union and enjoyment -- in whichAuto-modernized we find that our satisfaction and blessedness doesAuto-modernized consist. Love in general unites the mind toAuto-modernized the object -- the person loving toAuto-modernized the thing or person beloved. So is it expressed in an instance of human, temporary, changeable love, -- namely, that of Jonathan to David. His soul "was knit with the soul of David, and he loved him as his own soul," 1 Samuel 18:1 Love had so effectually united them, as that the soul of David was as his own. Hence are those expressions of this divine love, by "cleaving toAuto-modernized God, following hard after him, thirsting, panting after him," with the like intimations of the most earnest endeavours of our nature after union and enjoyment.

When the soul hasAuto-modernized a view by faith (which nothing else can give it) of the goodness of God as manifested in Christ -- that is of the essential excellencies of his nature as exerting themselves in him -- it reachesAuto-modernized after him with its most earnest embraces, and is restless until it comes toAuto-modernized perfect fruition. It sees in God the fountain of life, and would drink of the "river of his pleasures," Psalms 36:8-9 -- that in his "presence is fulness of joy, and at his right hand are pleasures for evermore," Psalms 16:11 It longs and pants to drink of that fountain -- to bathe itself in that river of pleasures; and in whichAuto-modernized it comes short of present enjoyment, it lives in hopes that when we "awake, it shall be satisfied with his likeness," Psalms 17:15 There is nothing grievous toAuto-modernized a soul filled with this love, but what keeps it from the full enjoyment of these excellencies of God. What doesAuto-modernized so naturally and necessarily, it groans under. Such is our present state in the body, in whichAuto-modernized, in some sense, we are "absent from the Lord," 2 Corinthians 5:4, 8-9 And what doesAuto-modernized so morally, in the deviations of its will and affections, as sin -- it hates and abhors and loathes itself for. Under the conduct of this love, the whole tendency of the soul is toAuto-modernized the enjoyment of God; -- it would be lost in itself, and found in him, -- nothing in itself, and all in him. Absolute complacency in thisAuto-modernized -- that God is what he is, that he should be what he is, and nothing else, and that as such we may be united toAuto-modernized him, and enjoy Him according to the capacity of our natures is the life of divine love.

(2.) It is a love of assimilation. It contains in it a desire and intense endeavour to be like toAuto-modernized God, according toAuto-modernized our capacity and measure. The soul sees all goodness, and consequently all that is amiable and lovely, in God -- the want of all which it finds in itself. The fruition of his goodness is that which it longs for as its utmost end, and conformity toAuto-modernized it as the means of thatAuto-modernized. There is no man who loves not God sincerely, but indeed he would have him to be somewhat that he is not, that he might be the more like toAuto-modernized him. This such persons are pleased withal whilst they can fancy it in any thing, Psalms 50:21 They that love him, would have him be all that he is -- as he is, and nothing else; and would be themselves like toAuto-modernized him. And as love hasAuto-modernized this tendency, and is that which gives disquietAuto-modernized toAuto-modernized the soul when and in whichAuto-modernized we are unlike toAuto-modernized God, so it stirs up constant endeavours after assimilation toAuto-modernized him, and hasAuto-modernized a principal efficacy toAuto-modernized that end. Love is the principle that actually assimilates and conforms us toAuto-modernized God, as faith is the principle which originally disposesAuto-modernized to thatAuto-modernized. In our renovation into the image of God, the transforming power is radically seated in faith, but acts itself by love. Love proceeding from faith gradually changesAuto-modernized the soul into the likeness of God; and the more it is in exercise, the more is that change effected.

To labour after conformity toAuto-modernized God by outward actions only, is to make an image of the living God, hewed out of the stock of a dead tree. It is from this vital principle of love that we are not forced into it as by engines, but naturally grow up into the likeness and image of God. For when it is duly affected with the excellencies of God in Christ, it fills the mind with thoughts and contemplations on them, and excites all the affections toAuto-modernized a delight in them. And where the soul acts itself constantly in the mind's contemplation, and the delight of the affections, it will produce assimilation toAuto-modernized the object of them. To love God is the only way and means to be like toAuto-modernized him.

(3.) It is a love of complacency, and in thatAuto-modernized of benevolence. Upon that view which we have by spiritual light and faith of the divine goodness, exerting itself in the way before described, our souls do approve of all that is in God, applaud it, adore it, and acquiesce in it. Hence two great duties do arise, and upon thisAuto-modernized do they depend. First, Joyful ascriptions of glory and honour toAuto-modernized God. All praise and thanksgiving, all blessing, all assignation of glory toAuto-modernized him, because of his excellencies and perfections, do arise from our satisfactory complacence in them. The righteous "rejoice in the Lord, and give thanks at the remembrance of his holiness," Psalms 97:12 They are so pleased and satisfied at the remembrance of God's holiness, that it fills their hearts with joy and causesAuto-modernized them to break forth in praises. Praise is nothing but an outward expression of the inward complacency of our hearts in the divine perfections and their operations. And, secondly, Love in thisAuto-modernized acts itself by benevolence, as the constant inclination of the mind toAuto-modernized all things in whichAuto-modernized the glory of God is concerned. It wills all the things in whichAuto-modernized the name of God may be sanctified, his praises made glorious, and his will done on earth as it is in heaven. As God says of his own love toAuto-modernized us, that "he will rest in his love, he will joy over us [thee] with singing," Zephaniah 3:17 -- as having the greatest complacency in it, rejoicing over us with his "whole heart and his whole soul," Jeremiah 32:41; -- so, according toAuto-modernized our measure, do we by love rest in the glorious excellencies of God, rejoicing in them with our whole hearts and our whole souls.

(4.) This divine love is a love of friendship. The communion which we have with God in thatAuto-modernized is so intimate, and accompanied with such spiritual boldness, as gives it that denomination. So Abraham was called "The friend of God," Isaiah 41:8; James 2:23 And because of that mutual trust which is between friends, "the secret of the Lord is with them that fear him, and he will show them his covenant," Psalms 25:14 For, as our Saviour teachesAuto-modernized us, "servants" -- that is, those who are so, and no more -- "know not what their lord doesAuto-modernized;" he rules them, commands them, or requires obedience from them; but as toAuto-modernized his secret -- his design and purpose, his counsel and love -- they know nothing of it. But saysAuto-modernized he toAuto-modernized his disciples, "I have called you friends, for all things that I have heard of my Father I have made known toAuto-modernized you," John 15:15 He proves them to be rightly called his friends, because of the communication of the secret of his mind toAuto-modernized them.

This is the great difference between them who are only servants in the house of God, and those who are so servants as to be friends also. The same commands are given toAuto-modernized all equally, and the same duties are required of all equally, inasmuch as they are equally servants; but those who are no more but so, know nothing of the secret counsel, love, and grace of God, in a due manner. For the natural man receivesAuto-modernized not the things that are of God. Hence all their obedience is servile. They know neither the principal motives toAuto-modernized it nor the ends of it. But they who are so servants as to be friends also, they know what their Lord doesAuto-modernized; the secret of the Lord is with them, and he shows them his covenant. They are admitted into an intimate acquaintance with the mind of Christ, ("we have the mind of Christ," 1 Corinthians 2:16,) and are upon thatAuto-modernized encouraged to perform the obedience of servants, with the love and delight of friends.

The same love of friendship is expressed by that intimate converse with, and specialAuto-modernized residence that is between God and believers. God dwellsAuto-modernized in them, and they dwell in God; for God is love, 1 John 4:16 "If a man," saysAuto-modernized the Lord Christ, "love me, he will keep my words: and my Father will love him, and we will come toAuto-modernized him, and make our abode with him," John 14:23; and, "If any man hear my voice, and open the door, I will come in to him, and will sup with him, and he with me," Revelation of John 3:20 These are not empty sound of words; -- there is substance under them, there is truth in them. Those whose hearts are duly exercised in and toAuto-modernized the love of God have experience of the refreshing approaches both of the Father and of the Son toAuto-modernized their souls, in the communications of a sense of their love, and pledges of their abode with them.

These things have I briefly premised, concerning the nature of divine love, that we may the better apprehend what we understand by it, in the application of it toAuto-modernized the person of Christ. For --

1. The formal object of this love is the essential properties of the divine nature -- its infinite goodness in particular. Wherever these are, there is the object and reason of this love. But they are all of them in the person of the Son, no less than in the person of the Father. As, therefore, we love the Father on this account, so are we to love the Son also. But --

2. The Person of Christ is to be considered as he was incarnate, or clothed with our nature. And this takes nothing off from the formal reason of this love, but only makes an addition toAuto-modernized the motives of it. This, indeed, for a season veiled the loveliness of his divine excellencies, and so turned aside the eyes of many from him. For when he took on him "the form of a servant, and made himself of no reputation," he had, toAuto-modernized them who looked on him with carnal eyes, "neither form nor comeliness," that he should be desired or be loved. NeverthelessAuto-modernized, the entire person of Christ, God and man, is the object of this divine love, in all the acts of the whole exercise of it. That single effect of infinite wisdom and grace, in the union of the divine and human natures in the one person of the Son of God, renders him the object of this love in a peculiar manner. The way through whichAuto-modernized we may attain this peculiar love, and the motives toAuto-modernized it, shall close these considerations.

A due consideration of, and meditation on, the proposal of the person of Christ toAuto-modernized us in the Scripture, are the proper foundation of this love. This is the formal reason of our faith in him, and love toAuto-modernized him. He is so proposed toAuto-modernized us in the Scripture, that we may believe in him and love him, and for that very end. And in particular with respect toAuto-modernized our love, to ingenerate it in us, and to excite it toAuto-modernized its due exercise, are those excellencies of his person -- as the principal effect of divine wisdom and goodness, which we have before insisted on -- frequently proposed toAuto-modernized us. To this end is he represented as "altogether lovely," and the specialAuto-modernized glories of his person are delineated, yea, drawn to the life, in the holy records of the Old and New Testaments. It is no work of fancy or imagination -- it is not the feigning images in our minds of such things as are meet to satisfy our carnal affections, to excite and act them; but it is a due adherence toAuto-modernized that object which is represented toAuto-modernized faith in the proposal of the gospel. In thatAuto-modernized, as in a glass, do we behold the glory of Christ, who is the image of the invisible God, and have our souls filled with transforming affections toAuto-modernized him.

The whole Book of Canticles is nothing but a mystical declaration of the mutual love between Christ and the church. And it is expressed by all such ways and means as may represent it intense, fervent, and exceeding all other love whatever; which none, I suppose, will deny, at least on the part of Christ. And a great part of it consists in such descriptions of the person of Christ and his love as may render him amiable and desirable toAuto-modernized our souls, even "altogether lovely." To what end doesAuto-modernized the Holy Spirit so graphically describe and represent toAuto-modernized us the beauty and desirableness of his person, if it be not to ingenerate love in us toAuto-modernized him? All want of love toAuto-modernized him on this proposal is the effect of prevalent unbelief. It is pretended that the descriptions given of Christ in this book are allegorical, from whereAuto-modernized nothing can be gathered or concluded. But God forbid we should so reflect on the wisdom and love of the Holy Spirit toAuto-modernized the church -- that he hasAuto-modernized proposed toAuto-modernized the faith of the church an empty sound and noise of words, without mind or sense. The expressions he uses are figurative, and the whole nature of the discourse, as toAuto-modernized its outward structure, is allegorical. But the things intended are real and substantial; and the metaphors used in the expression of them are suited, in a due attendance toAuto-modernized the analogy of faith, to convey a spiritual understanding and sense of the things themselves proposed in them. The church of God will not part with the unspeakable advantage and consolation -- those supports of faith and incentives of love -- which it receives by that divine proposal of the person of Christ and his love which is made in thatAuto-modernized, because some men have no experience of them nor understanding in them. The faith and love of believers is not to be regulated by the ignorance and boldness of them who have neither the one nor the other. The title of the 45^th Psalm is, shyr ydydt, "A song of loves;" -- that is, of the mutual love of Christ and the church. And toAuto-modernized this end -- that our souls may be stirred up toAuto-modernized the most ardent affection towards him -- is a description given us of his person, as "altogether lovely." To what other end is he so evidently delineated in the whole harmony of his divine beauties by the pencil of the Holy Spirit?

Not to insist on particular testimonies, it is evident toAuto-modernized all whose eyes are opened to discern these things, that there is no property of the divine nature which is peculiarly amiable -- such as are goodness, grace, love, and bounty, with infinite power and holiness -- but it is represented and proposed toAuto-modernized us in the person of the Son of God, to this end, that we should love him above all, and cleave toAuto-modernized him. There is nothing in the human nature, in that fulness of grace and truth which dwelt in thatAuto-modernized, in that inhabitation of the Spirit which was in him without measure, in any thing of those "all things" in whichAuto-modernized he hasAuto-modernized the pre-eminence -- nothing in his love, condescension, grace, and mercy -- nothing in the work that he fulfilled, what he did and suffered in thatAuto-modernized -- nothing in the benefits we receive thereby -- nothing in the power and glory that he is exalted toAuto-modernized at the right hand of God -- but it is set forth in the Scripture and proposed toAuto-modernized us, that, believing in him, we may love him with all our hearts and souls. And, besides all this, that singular, that infinite effect of divine wisdom, to whichAuto-modernized there is nothing like in all the works of God, and with whichAuto-modernized none of them may be compared -- namely, the constitution of his person by the union of his natures in thatAuto-modernized, through whichAuto-modernized he becomes toAuto-modernized us the image of the invisible God, and in whichAuto-modernized all the blessed excellencies of his distinct natures are made most illustriously conspicuous in becoming one entire principle of all his mediatory operations on our behalf -- is proposed toAuto-modernized us as the complete object of our faith and love. This is that person whose loveliness and beauty all the angels of God, all the holy ones above, do eternally admire and adore. In him are the infinite treasures of divine wisdom and goodness continually represented toAuto-modernized them. This is he who is the joy, the delight, the love, the glory of the church below. "Thou whom our souls do love," is the title through whichAuto-modernized they know him and converse with him, Song of Solomon 1:7; iii. 1, 4. This is he who is the Desire of all nations -- the Beloved of God and men.
The mutual intercourse on this ground of love between Christ and the church, is the life and soul of the whole creation; for on the account of thisAuto-modernized all things consist in him.

There is more glory under the eye of God, in the sighs, groans, and mournings of poor souls filled with the love of Christ, after the enjoyment of him according to his promises -- in their fervent prayers for his manifestation of himself toAuto-modernized them -- in the refreshments and unspeakable joys which they have in his gracious visits and embraces of his love -- than in the thrones and diadems of all the monarchs on the earth. Nor will they themselves part with the ineffable satisfactions which they have in these things, for all that this world can do for them or toAuto-modernized them. "Mallem ruere cum Christo, quam regnare cum C�sare." These things have not only rendered prisons and dungeons more desirable toAuto-modernized them than the most goodly palaces, on future accounts, but have made them really places of such refreshment and joys as men shall seek in vain to extract out of all the comforts that this world can afford.
O curv� in terras anim� et coelestium inanes!

Many there are who, not comprehending, not being affected with, that divine, spiritual description of the person of Christ which is given us by the Holy Ghost in the Scripture, do feign toAuto-modernized themselves false representations of him by images and pictures, so as to excite carnal and corrupt affections in their minds. By the help of their outward senses, they reflect on their imaginations the shape of a human body, cast into postures and circumstances dolorous or triumphant; and so, by the working of their fancy, raise a commotion of mind in themselves, which they suppose to be love toAuto-modernized Christ. But all these idols are teachers of lies. The true beauty and amiableness of the person of Christ, which is the formal object and cause of divine love, is so far from being represented in thisAuto-modernized, as that the mind is thereby wholly diverted from the contemplation of it. For no more can be so pictured toAuto-modernized us but what may belong toAuto-modernized a mere man, and what is arbitrarily referred toAuto-modernized Christ, not by faith, but by corrupt imagination.

The beauty of the person of Christ, as represented in the Scripture, consists in things invisible toAuto-modernized the eyes of flesh. They are such as no hand of man can represent or shadow. It is the eye of faith alone that can see this King in his beauty. What else can contemplate on the untreated glories of his divine nature? Can the hand of man represent the union of his natures in the same person, in whichAuto-modernized he is peculiarly amiable? What eye can discern the mutual communications of the properties of his different natures in the same person, which depends upon thatAuto-modernized, from whereAuto-modernized it is that God laid down his life for us, and purchased his church with his own blood? In these things, O vain man! doesAuto-modernized the loveliness of the person of Christ toAuto-modernized the souls of believers consist, and not in those strokes of art which fancy hasAuto-modernized guided a skilful hand and pencil toAuto-modernized. And what eye of flesh can discern the inhabitation of the Spirit in all fulness in the human nature? Can his condescension, his love, his grace, his power, his compassion, his offices, his fitness and ability to save sinners, be deciphered on a tablet, or engraven on wood or stone? However such pictures may be adorned, however beautified and enriched, they are not that Christ which the soul of the spouse doesAuto-modernized love; -- they are not any means of representing his love toAuto-modernized us, or of conveying our love toAuto-modernized him; -- they only divert the minds of superstitious persons from the Son of God, toAuto-modernized the embraces of a cloud, composed of fancy and imagination.

Others there are who abhor these idols, and when they have so done, commit sacrilege. As they reject images, so they seem to do all love toAuto-modernized the person of Christ, distinct from other acts of obedience, as a fond imagination. But the most superstitious love toAuto-modernized Christ -- that is, love acted in ways tainted with superstition -- is better than none at all. But with what eyes do such persons read the Scriptures? With what hearts do they consider them? What do they conceive is the intention of the Holy Ghost in all those descriptions which he gives us of the person of Christ as amiable and desirable above all things, making wherewithal a proposal of him toAuto-modernized our affections -- inciting us to receive him by faith, and to cleave toAuto-modernized him in love? yea, to what end is our nature endued with this affection -- toAuto-modernized what end is the power of it renewed in us by the sanctification of the Holy Spirit -- if it may not be fixed on this most proper and excellent object of it?

This is the foundation of our love toAuto-modernized Christ -- namely, the revelation and proposal of him toAuto-modernized us in the Scripture as altogether lovely. The discovery that is made in thatAuto-modernized of the glorious excellencies and endowments of his person -- of his love, his goodness, and grace -- of his worth and work -- is that which engagesAuto-modernized the affections of believers toAuto-modernized him. It may be said, that if there be such a proposal of him made toAuto-modernized all promiscuously, then all would equally discern his amiableness and be affected with it, who assent equally toAuto-modernized the truth of that revelation. But it hasAuto-modernized always fallen out otherwise. In the days of his flesh, some that looked on him could see neither "form nor comeliness" in him thereforeAuto-modernized he should be desired; others saw his glory -- "glory as of the only-begotten of the Father, full of grace and truth." To some he is precious; toAuto-modernized others he is disallowed and rejected -- a stone which the builders refused, when others brought it forth, crying, "Grace, grace toAuto-modernized it!" as the head of the corner. Some can see nothing but weakness in him; toAuto-modernized others the wisdom and power of God do evidently shine forth in him. ThereforeAuto-modernized it must be said, that notwithstanding that open, plain representation that is made of him in the Scripture, unless the Holy Spirit gives us eyes to discern it, and circumcise our hearts by the cutting off corrupt prejudices and all effects of unbelief, implanting in them, by the efficacy of his grace, this blessed affection of love toAuto-modernized him, all these things will make no impression on our minds.

As it was with the people on the giving of the law, notwithstanding all the great and mighty works which God had wrought among them, yet having not given them "a heart to perceive, and eyes to see, and ears to hear" -- which he affirms that he had not done, Deuteronomy 29:4, -- they were not moved toAuto-modernized faith or obedience by them; so is it in the preaching of the gospel. Notwithstanding all the blessed revelation that is made of the excellencies of the person of Christ in thatAuto-modernized, yet those into whose hearts God doesAuto-modernized not shine to give the knowledge of his glory in his face, can discern nothing of it, nor are their hearts affected with it.

We do not, therefore, in these things, follow "cunningly-devised fables." We do not indulge toAuto-modernized our own fancies and imaginations; -- they are not unaccountable raptures or ecstasies which are pretended toAuto-modernized, nor such an artificial concatenation of thoughts as some ignorant of these things do boast that they can give an account of. Our love to Christ arisesAuto-modernized alone from the revelation that is made of him in the Scripture -- is ingenerated, regulated, measured, and is to be judged thereby.

div.osisID: Chapter 14 Motives to the Love of Christ Themotives to this love of Christ is the last thing on this head of our religious respect to him that I shall speak to
div.title: Chapter 14 Motives to the Love of Christ. Themotives to this love of Christ is the last thing, on this head of our religious respect to him, that I shall speak to.
div.p: When God required of the church the first and highest act of religion, the sole foundation of all others -- namely, to take him as their God, to own, believe, and trust in him alone as such, (which is wholly due toAuto-modernized him for what he is, without any other consideration whatever,) -- yet he thought meet to add a motive toAuto-modernized the performance of that duty from what he had done for them, Exodus 20:2-3 The sense of the first command is, that we should take him alone for our God; for he is so, and there is no other. But in the prescription of this duty toAuto-modernized the church, he minds them of the benefits which they had received from him in bringing them out of the house of bondage.

God, in his wisdom and grace, ordersAuto-modernized all the causes and reasons of our duty, so as that all the rational powers and faculties of our souls may be exercised in thatAuto-modernized. ThereforeAuto-modernized he doesAuto-modernized not only propose himself toAuto-modernized us, nor is Christ merely proposed toAuto-modernized us as the proper object of our affections, but he calls us also toAuto-modernized the consideration of all those things that may satisfy our souls that it is the most just, necessary, reasonable and advantageous course for us so to fix our affections an him.

And these considerations are taken from all that he did for us, with the reasons and grounds why he did it. We love him principally and ultimately for what he is; but nextly and immediately for what he did. What he did for us is first proposed toAuto-modernized us, and it is that which our souls are first affected withal. For they are originally acted in all things by a sense of the want which they have, and a desire of the blessedness which they have not. This directs them toAuto-modernized what he hasAuto-modernized done for sinners; but that leads immediately toAuto-modernized the consideration of what he is in himself. And when our love is fixed on him or his person, then all those things with whichAuto-modernized, from a sense of our own wants and desires, we were first affected, become motives toAuto-modernized the confirming and increasing of that love. This is the constant method of the Scripture; it first proposes toAuto-modernized us what the Lord Christ hasAuto-modernized done for us, especially in the discharge of his sacerdotal office, in his oblation and intercession, with the benefits which we receive thereby. Hereby it leads us toAuto-modernized his person, and pressesAuto-modernized the consideration of all other things to engage our love toAuto-modernized him. See Philippians 2:5-11, with Philippians 3:8-11

Motives toAuto-modernized the love of Christ are so great, so many, so diffused through the whole dispensation of God in him toAuto-modernized us, as that they can by no hand be fully expressed, let it be allowed ever so much to enlarge in the declaration of them; much less can they be represented in that short discourse of whichAuto-modernized but a very small part is allotted toAuto-modernized their consideration -- such as ours is at present. The studying, the collection of them or so many of them as we are able, the meditation on them and improvement of them, are among the principal duties of our whole lives. What I shall offer is the reduction of them toAuto-modernized these two heads: 1. The acts of Christ, which is the substance of them; and, 2. The spring and fountain of those acts, which is the life of them.

1. In general they are all the acts of his mediatory office, with all the fruits of them, of whichAuto-modernized we are made partners. There is not any thing that he did or doesAuto-modernized, in the discharge of his mediatory office, from the first susception of it in his incarnation in the womb of the blessed Virgin toAuto-modernized his present intercession in heaven, but is an effectual motive toAuto-modernized the love of him; and as such is proposed toAuto-modernized us in the Scripture. Whatever he did or doesAuto-modernized with or towards us in the name of God, as the king and prophet of the church -- whatever he did or doesAuto-modernized with God for us, as our high priest -- it all speaks this language in the hearts of them that believe: O love the Lord Jesus in sincerity.

The consideration of what Christ thus did and doesAuto-modernized for us is inseparable from that of the benefits which we receive thereby. A due mixture of both these -- of what he did for us, and what we obtain thereby -- comprisesAuto-modernized the substance of these motives: "Who loved me, and gave himself for me" -- "Who loved us, and washed us in his own blood, and made us kings and priests toAuto-modernized God" -- "For thou wast slain, and hast bought us toAuto-modernized God with thy blood." And both these are of a transcendent nature, requiring our love to be so also. Who is able to comprehend the glory of the mediatory acting of the Son of God, in the assumption of our nature -- in what he did and suffered in thatAuto-modernized? And for us, eye hasAuto-modernized not seen, nor ear heard, nor can it enter into the heart of man to conceive, what we receive thereby. The least benefit, and that obtained by the least expense of trouble or charge, deservesAuto-modernized love, and leavesAuto-modernized the brand of a crime where it is not so entertained. What, then, do the greatest deserve, and thou procured by the greatest expense -- even the price of the blood of the Son of God?

If we have any faith concerning these things, it will produce love, as that love will obedience. Whatever we profess concerning them, it springs from tradition and opinion, and not from faith, if it engage not our souls into the love of him. The frame of heart which ensues on the real faith of these things is expressed, Psalms 103:1-5, "Bless the Lord, O my soul; and all that is within me, bless his holy name. Bless the Lord, O my soul, and forget not all his benefits; who forgivesAuto-modernized all thine iniquities; who healsAuto-modernized all thy diseases; who redeemsAuto-modernized thy life from destruction; who crownsAuto-modernized thee with lovingkindness and tender mercies; who satisfiesAuto-modernized thy mouth with good things; so that thy youth is renewed like the eagle's." Let men pretend what they will, there needs no greater, no other evidence, to prove that any one doesAuto-modernized not really believe the things that are reported in the Gospel, concerning the mediatory acting of Christ, or that he hasAuto-modernized no experience in his own soul and conscience of the fruits and effects of them, than this -- that his heart is not engaged by them toAuto-modernized the most ardent love towards his person.

He is no Christian who lives not much in the meditation of the mediation of Christ, and the specialAuto-modernized acts of it. Some may more abound in that work than others, as it is fixed, formed and regular; some may be more able than others to dispose their thought concerning them into method and order; some may be more diligent than others in the observation of times for the solemn performance of this duty; some may be able to rise to higher and clearer apprehensions of them than others. But as for those, the bent of whose minds doesAuto-modernized not lie towards thoughts of them -- whose hearts are not on all occasions retreating toAuto-modernized the remembrance of them -- who embrace not all opportunities to call them over as they are able -- on what grounds can they be esteemed Christians? how do they live by the faith of the Son of God? Are the great things of the Gospel, of the mediation of Christ, proposed toAuto-modernized us, as those which we may think of when we have nothing else to do, that we may meditate upon or neglect at our pleasure -- as those in whichAuto-modernized our concernAuto-modernized is so small as that they must give place toAuto-modernized all other occasions or diversions whatever? Nay; if our minds are not filled with these things -- if Christ doesAuto-modernized not dwell plentifully in our hearts by faith -- if our souls are not possessed with them, and in their whole inward frame and constitution so cut into this mould as to be led by a natural complacency toAuto-modernized a converse with them -- we are strangers toAuto-modernized the life of faith. And if we are thus conversant about these things, they will engage our hearts into the love of the person of Christ. To suppose the contrary, is indeed to deny the truth and reality of them all, and to turn the Gospel into a fable.

Take one instance from among the rest -- namely, his death. HasAuto-modernized he the heart of a Christian, who doesAuto-modernized not often meditate on the death of his Saviour, who doesAuto-modernized not derive his life from it? Who can look into the Gospel and not fix on those lines which either immediately and directly, or through some other paths of divine grace and wisdom, do lead him to thatAuto-modernized? And can any have believing thoughts concerning the death of Christ, and not have his heart affected with ardent love toAuto-modernized his person? Christ in the Gospel "is evidently set forth, crucified" before us. Can any by the eye of faith look on this bleeding, dying Redeemer, and suppose love toAuto-modernized his person to be nothing but the work of fancy or imagination? They know the contrary, who "always bear about in the body the dying of the Lord Jesus," as the apostle speaks, 2 Corinthians 4:10 As his whole "name," in all that he did, is "as ointment poured forth," for which "the virgins love him," Song of Solomon 1:3, -- so this precious perfume of his death is that with whichAuto-modernized their hearts are ravished in a peculiar manner.

Again: as there can be no faith in Christ where there is no love toAuto-modernized him on the account of his mediatory acts; so, where it is not, the want of it castsAuto-modernized persons under the highest guilt of ingratitude that our nature is liable toAuto-modernized. The highest aggravation of the sin of angels was their ingratitude toAuto-modernized their Maker.
